5    *Keyboard Accessible*: 5    *Keyboard Accessible*:
6    Understanding Guideline 2.1 6    Understanding Guideline 2.1
7  7 
8    *Guideline 2.1: * Make all functionality available from a keyboard. 8    *Guideline 2.1: * Make all functionality available from a keyboard.
9  9 
10  10 
11      Intent of Guideline 2.1 11      Intent of Guideline 2.1
12  12 
13If all functionality 13If all functionality
14<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#functiondef> can be 14<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#functiondef> can be
15achieved using the keyboard, it can be accomplished by keyboard users, 15achieved using the keyboard, it can be accomplished by keyboard users,
16by speech input (which creates keyboard input), by mouse (using 16by speech input (which creates keyboard input), by mouse (using
17on-screen keyboards), and by a wide variety of assistive technologies 17on-screen keyboards), and by a wide variety of assistive technologies
18that create simulated keystrokes as their output. No other input form 18that create simulated keystrokes as their output. No other input form
19has this flexibility or is universally supported and operable by people 19has this flexibility or is universally supported and operable by people
20with different disabilities, as long as the keyboard input is not 20with different disabilities, as long as the keyboard input is not
21time-dependent. 21time-dependent.
22  22 
23Note that providing universal keyboard input does not mean that other 23Note that providing universal keyboard input does not mean that other
24types of input should not be supported. Optimized speech input, 24types of input should not be supported. Optimized speech input,
25optimized mouse/pointer input, etc., are also good. The key is to 25optimized mouse/pointer input, etc., are also good. The key is to
26provide keyboard input and control as well. 26provide keyboard input and control as well.
27  27 
28Some devices do not have native keyboards—for example, a PDA or cell 28Some devices do not have native keyboards—for example, a PDA or cell
29phone. If these devices have a Web browsing capability, however, they 29phone. If these devices have a Web browsing capability, however, they
30will have some means of generating text or "keystrokes". This guideline 30will have some means of generating text or "keystrokes". This guideline
31uses the term "keyboard interface 31uses the term "keyboard interface
32<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keybrd-interfacedef>" to 32<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keybrd-interfacedef>" to
33acknowledge that Web content should be controlled from keystrokes that 33acknowledge that Web content should be controlled from keystrokes that
34may come from a keyboard, keyboard emulator, or other hardware or 34may come from a keyboard, keyboard emulator, or other hardware or
35software that generates keyboard or text input. 35software that generates keyboard or text input.
36  36 
37  37 
38      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 2.1 (not success criteria specific) 38      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 2.1 (not success criteria specific)
39  39 
40Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this 40Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this
41guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success 41guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success
42Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for 42Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for
43addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success 43addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success
44criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or 44criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or
45sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types 45sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types
46of Web content more accessible to more people. 46of Web content more accessible to more people.
47  47 
48  * All advisory techniques for this guideline relate to specific 48  * All advisory techniques for this guideline relate to specific
49    success criteria. 49    success criteria.

52    *Keyboard*: 52    *Keyboard*:
53    Understanding SC 2.1.1 53    Understanding SC 2.1.1
54  54 
55    *2.1.1 55    *2.1.1
56    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keyboard-operation-keyboard-operable> 56    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keyboard-operation-keyboard-operable>
57    Keyboard:* All functionality 57    Keyboard:* All functionality
58    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#functiondef> of the 58    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#functiondef> of the
59    content is operable through a keyboard interface 59    content is operable through a keyboard interface
60    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keybrd-interfacedef> 60    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keybrd-interfacedef>
61    without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except 61    without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except
62    where the underlying function requires input that depends on the 62    where the underlying function requires input that depends on the
63    path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints. (Level A) 63    path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints. (Level A)
64  64 
65    /Note 1: /This exception relates to the underlying function, not the 65    /Note 1: /This exception relates to the underlying function, not the
66    input technique. For example, if using handwriting to enter text, 66    input technique. For example, if using handwriting to enter text,
67    the input technique (handwriting) requires path-dependent input but 67    the input technique (handwriting) requires path-dependent input but
68    the underlying function (text input) does not. 68    the underlying function (text input) does not.
69  69 
70    /Note 2: /This does not forbid and should not discourage providing 70    /Note 2: /This does not forbid and should not discourage providing
71    mouse input or other input methods in addition to keyboard operation. 71    mouse input or other input methods in addition to keyboard operation.
72  72 
73  73 
74      Intent of this Success Criterion 74      Intent of this Success Criterion
75  75 
76The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that, wherever 76The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that, wherever
77possible, content can be operated through a keyboard or keyboard 77possible, content can be operated through a keyboard or keyboard
78interface (so an alternate keyboard can be used). When content can be 78interface (so an alternate keyboard can be used). When content can be
79operated through a keyboard or alternate keyboard, it is operable by 79operated through a keyboard or alternate keyboard, it is operable by
80people with no vision (who cannot use devices such as mice that require 80people with no vision (who cannot use devices such as mice that require
81eye-hand coordination) as well as by people who must use alternate 81eye-hand coordination) as well as by people who must use alternate
82keyboards or input devices that act as keyboard emulators. Keyboard 82keyboards or input devices that act as keyboard emulators. Keyboard
83emulators include speech input software, sip-and-puff software, 83emulators include speech input software, sip-and-puff software,
84on-screen keyboards, scanning software and a variety of assistive 84on-screen keyboards, scanning software and a variety of assistive
85technologies and alternate keyboards. Individuals with low vision also 85technologies and alternate keyboards. Individuals with low vision also
86may have trouble tracking a pointer and find the use of software much 86may have trouble tracking a pointer and find the use of software much
87easier (or only possible) if they can control it from the keyboard. 87easier (or only possible) if they can control it from the keyboard.
88  88 
89Examples of "specific timings for individual keystrokes" include 89Examples of "specific timings for individual keystrokes" include
90situations where a user would be required to repeat or execute multiple 90situations where a user would be required to repeat or execute multiple
91keystrokes within a short period of time or where a key must be held 91keystrokes within a short period of time or where a key must be held
92down for an extended period before the keystroke is registered. 92down for an extended period before the keystroke is registered.
93  93 
94The phrase "except where the underlying function requires input that 94The phrase "except where the underlying function requires input that
95depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints" 95depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints"
96is included to separate those things that cannot reasonably be 96is included to separate those things that cannot reasonably be
97controlled from a keyboard. 97controlled from a keyboard.
98  98 
99Most actions carried out by a pointing device can also be done from the 99Most actions carried out by a pointing device can also be done from the
100keyboard (for example, clicking, selecting, moving, sizing). However, 100keyboard (for example, clicking, selecting, moving, sizing). However,
101there is a small class of input that is done with a pointing device that 101there is a small class of input that is done with a pointing device that
102cannot be done from the keyboard in any known fashion without requiring 102cannot be done from the keyboard in any known fashion without requiring
103an inordinate number of keystrokes. Free hand drawing, watercolor 103an inordinate number of keystrokes. Free hand drawing, watercolor
104painting, and flying a helicopter through an obstacle course are all 104painting, and flying a helicopter through an obstacle course are all
105examples of functions that require path dependent input. Drawing 105examples of functions that require path dependent input. Drawing
106straight lines, regular geometric shapes, re-sizing windows and dragging 106straight lines, regular geometric shapes, re-sizing windows and dragging
107objects to a location (when the path to that location is not relevant) 107objects to a location (when the path to that location is not relevant)
108do not require path dependent input. 108do not require path dependent input.
109  109 
110The use of MouseKeys would not satisfy this Success Criterion because it 110The use of MouseKeys would not satisfy this Success Criterion because it
111is not a keyboard equivalent to the application; it is a mouse 111is not a keyboard equivalent to the application; it is a mouse
112equivalent (i.e., it looks like a mouse to the application). 112equivalent (i.e., it looks like a mouse to the application).
113  113 
114It is assumed that the design of user input features takes into account 114It is assumed that the design of user input features takes into account
115that operating system keyboard accessibility features may be in use. For 115that operating system keyboard accessibility features may be in use. For
116example, modifier key locking may be turned on. Content continues to 116example, modifier key locking may be turned on. Content continues to
117function in such an environment, not sending events that would collide 117function in such an environment, not sending events that would collide
118with the modifier key lock to produce unexpected results. 118with the modifier key lock to produce unexpected results.
119  119

121        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.1.1 121        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.1.1
122  122 
123  * 123  *
124  124 
125    People who are blind (who cannot use devices such as mice that 125    People who are blind (who cannot use devices such as mice that
126    require eye-hand coordination) 126    require eye-hand coordination)
127  127 
128  * 128  *
129  129 
130    People with low vision (who may have trouble finding or tracking a 130    People with low vision (who may have trouble finding or tracking a
131    pointer indicator on screen) 131    pointer indicator on screen)
132  132 
133  * 133  *
134  134 
135    Some people with hand tremors find using a mouse very difficult and 135    Some people with hand tremors find using a mouse very difficult and
136    therefore usually use a keyboard 136    therefore usually use a keyboard
137  137 
138  138 
139      Examples of Success Criterion 2.1.1 139      Examples of Success Criterion 2.1.1
140  140 
141  * 141  *
142  142 
143    *Example 1: A drawing Program.* 143    *Example 1: A drawing Program.*
144  144 
145    A drawing program allows users to create, size, position and rotate 145    A drawing program allows users to create, size, position and rotate
146    objects from the keyboard. 146    objects from the keyboard.
147  147 
148  * 148  *
149  149 
150    *Example 2: A drag and Drop Feature.* 150    *Example 2: A drag and Drop Feature.*
151  151 
152    An application that uses drag and drop also supports "cut" and 152    An application that uses drag and drop also supports "cut" and
153    "paste" or form controls to move objects. 153    "paste" or form controls to move objects.
154  154 
155  * 155  *
156  156 
157    *Example 3: Moving between and connecting discrete points.* 157    *Example 3: Moving between and connecting discrete points.*
158  158 
159    A connect-the-dots program allows the user to move between dots on a 159    A connect-the-dots program allows the user to move between dots on a
160    screen and use the spacebar to connect the current dot to the 160    screen and use the spacebar to connect the current dot to the
161    previous one. 161    previous one.
162  162 
163  * 163  *
164  164 
165    *Example 4: Exception - Painting Program.* 165    *Example 4: Exception - Painting Program.*
166  166 
167    A watercolor painting program passes as an exception because the 167    A watercolor painting program passes as an exception because the
168    brush strokes vary depending on the speed and duration of the movements. 168    brush strokes vary depending on the speed and duration of the movements.
169  169 
170  * 170  *
171  171 
172    *Example 5: Exception - Model helicopter flight training simulator.* 172    *Example 5: Exception - Model helicopter flight training simulator.*
173  173 
174    A model helicopter flight training simulator passes as an exception 174    A model helicopter flight training simulator passes as an exception
175    because the nature of the simulator is to teach real-time behavior 175    because the nature of the simulator is to teach real-time behavior
176    of a model helicopter. 176    of a model helicopter.
177  177 
178  * 178  *
179  179 
180    *Example 6: A PDA with an optional keyboard* 180    *Example 6: A PDA with an optional keyboard*
181  181 
182    A PDA device that is usually operated via a stylus has an optional 182    A PDA device that is usually operated via a stylus has an optional
183    keyboard that can be attached. The keyboard allows full Web browsing 183    keyboard that can be attached. The keyboard allows full Web browsing
184    in standard fashion. The Web content is operable because it was 184    in standard fashion. The Web content is operable because it was
185    designed to work with keyboard-only access. 185    designed to work with keyboard-only access.

197Each numbered item in this section represents a technique or combination 197Each numbered item in this section represents a technique or combination
198of techniques that the WCAG Working Group deems sufficient for meeting 198of techniques that the WCAG Working Group deems sufficient for meeting
199this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success 199this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success
200Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements 200Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements
201<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have 201<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have
202been met. 202been met.

357    F54: Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.1 due to using only 357    F54: Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.1 due to using only
358    pointing-device-specific event handlers (including gesture) for a 358    pointing-device-specific event handlers (including gesture) for a
359    function <http://www.w3.org/TR/2012/NOTE-WCAG20-TECHS-20120103/F54> 359    function <http://www.w3.org/TR/2012/NOTE-WCAG20-TECHS-20120103/F54>
360  360

364    using script to remove focus when focus is received 364    using script to remove focus when focus is received

382  382 
383keyboard interface 383keyboard interface
384  384 
385    interface used by software to obtain keystroke input 385    interface used by software to obtain keystroke input
386  386 
387    /Note 1: /A keyboard interface allows users to provide keystroke 387    /Note 1: /A keyboard interface allows users to provide keystroke
388    input to programs even if the native technology does not contain a 388    input to programs even if the native technology does not contain a
389    keyboard. 389    keyboard.
390  390 
391    /Example: /A touchscreen PDA has a keyboard interface built into its 391    /Example: /A touchscreen PDA has a keyboard interface built into its
392    operating system as well as a connector for external keyboards. 392    operating system as well as a connector for external keyboards.
393    Applications on the PDA can use the interface to obtain keyboard 393    Applications on the PDA can use the interface to obtain keyboard
394    input either from an external keyboard or from other applications 394    input either from an external keyboard or from other applications
395    that provide simulated keyboard output, such as handwriting 395    that provide simulated keyboard output, such as handwriting
396    interpreters or speech-to-text applications with "keyboard 396    interpreters or speech-to-text applications with "keyboard
397    emulation" functionality. 397    emulation" functionality.
398  398 
399    /Note 2: /Operation of the application (or parts of the application) 399    /Note 2: /Operation of the application (or parts of the application)
400    through a keyboard-operated mouse emulator, such as MouseKeys, does 400    through a keyboard-operated mouse emulator, such as MouseKeys, does
401    not qualify as operation through a keyboard interface because 401    not qualify as operation through a keyboard interface because
402    operation of the program is through its pointing device interface, 402    operation of the program is through its pointing device interface,
403    not through its keyboard interface. 403    not through its keyboard interface.
404  404 
405------------------------------------------------------------------------ 405------------------------------------------------------------------------
406  406 
407  407 
408    *No Keyboard Trap*: 408    *No Keyboard Trap*:
409    Understanding SC 2.1.2 409    Understanding SC 2.1.2
410  410 
411    *2.1.2 411    *2.1.2
412    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keyboard-operation-trapping> 412    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keyboard-operation-trapping>
413    No Keyboard Trap:* If keyboard focus can be moved to a component of 413    No Keyboard Trap:* If keyboard focus can be moved to a component of
414    the page using a keyboard interface 414    the page using a keyboard interface
415    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keybrd-interfacedef>, then 415    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keybrd-interfacedef>, then
416    focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard 416    focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard
417    interface, and, if it requires more than unmodified arrow or tab 417    interface, and, if it requires more than unmodified arrow or tab
418    keys or other standard exit methods, the user is advised of the 418    keys or other standard exit methods, the user is advised of the
419    method for moving focus away. (Level A) 419    method for moving focus away. (Level A)
420  420 
421    /Note: /Since any content that does not meet this success criterion 421    /Note: /Since any content that does not meet this success criterion
422    can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all 422    can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all
423    content on the Web page (whether it is used to meet other success 423    content on the Web page (whether it is used to meet other success
424    criteria or not) must meet this success criterion. See /Conformance 424    criteria or not) must meet this success criterion. See /Conformance
425    Requirement 5: Non-Interference 425    Requirement 5: Non-Interference
426    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#cc5>/. 426    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#cc5>/.
427  427 
428  428 
429      Intent of this Success Criterion 429      Intent of this Success Criterion
430  430 
431The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that that content does 431The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that that content does
432not "trap" keyboard focus within subsections of content on a Web page. 432not "trap" keyboard focus within subsections of content on a Web page.
433This is a common problem when multiple formats are combined within a 433This is a common problem when multiple formats are combined within a
434page and rendered using plug-ins or embedded applications. 434page and rendered using plug-ins or embedded applications.
435  435 
436There may be times when the functionality of the Web page restricts the 436There may be times when the functionality of the Web page restricts the
437focus to a subsection of the content, as long as the user knows how to 437focus to a subsection of the content, as long as the user knows how to
438leave that state and "untrap" the focus. 438leave that state and "untrap" the focus.
439  439 
440  440 
441        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.1.2 441        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.1.2
442  442 
443  * 443  *
444  444 
445    People who rely on a keyboard or keyboard interface to use the Web 445    People who rely on a keyboard or keyboard interface to use the Web
446    including people who are blind and people with physical disabilities. 446    including people who are blind and people with physical disabilities.
447  447 
448  448 
449      Examples of Success Criterion 2.1.2 449      Examples of Success Criterion 2.1.2
450  450 
451  * 451  *
452  452 
453    *A calendar widget* 453    *A calendar widget*
454  454 
455    A calendar widget allows users to add, remove or update items in 455    A calendar widget allows users to add, remove or update items in
456    their calendar using the keyboard. The controls in the widget are 456    their calendar using the keyboard. The controls in the widget are
457    part of the tab order within the Web page, allowing users to tab 457    part of the tab order within the Web page, allowing users to tab
458    through the controls in the widget as well as to any links or 458    through the controls in the widget as well as to any links or
459    controls that follow. 459    controls that follow.
460  460 
461  * 461  *
462  462 
463    *A puzzle applet* 463    *A puzzle applet*
464  464 
465    Once a user tabs into an applet, further tabs and other keystrokes 465    Once a user tabs into an applet, further tabs and other keystrokes
466    are handled by the applet. Instructions describing the keystroke 466    are handled by the applet. Instructions describing the keystroke
467    used to exit the applet are provided prior to the applet as well as 467    used to exit the applet are provided prior to the applet as well as
468    within the applet itself. 468    within the applet itself.
469  469 
470  * 470  *
471  471 
472    *A modal dialog box* 472    *A modal dialog box*
473  473 
474    A Web application brings up a dialog box. At the bottom of the 474    A Web application brings up a dialog box. At the bottom of the
475    dialog are two buttons, Cancel and OK. When the dialog has been 475    dialog are two buttons, Cancel and OK. When the dialog has been
476    opened, focus is trapped within the dialog; tabbing from the last 476    opened, focus is trapped within the dialog; tabbing from the last
477    control in the dialog takes focus to the first control in the 477    control in the dialog takes focus to the first control in the
478    dialog. The dialog is dismissed by activating the Cancel button or 478    dialog. The dialog is dismissed by activating the Cancel button or
479    the OK button. 479    the OK button.

567    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keyboard-operation-all-funcs> 567    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#keyboard-operation-all-funcs>

569    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#functiondef> of the 569    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#functiondef> of the
570    content is operable through a keyboard interface 570    content is operable through a keyboard interface

572    without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes. (Level 572    without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes. (Level
573    AAA) 573    AAA)
574  574 
575  575 
576      Intent of this Success Criterion 576      Intent of this Success Criterion
577  577 
578The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that *all* content is 578The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that *all* content is
579operable from the keyboard. This is the same as Success Criterion 2.1.1, 579operable from the keyboard. This is the same as Success Criterion 2.1.1,
580except that no exceptions are allowed. This does not mean that content 580except that no exceptions are allowed. This does not mean that content
581where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of 581where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of
582the user's movement and not just the endpoints (excluded from the 582the user's movement and not just the endpoints (excluded from the
583requirements of 2.1.1) must be made keyboard accessible. Rather, it 583requirements of 2.1.1) must be made keyboard accessible. Rather, it
584means that content that uses path-dependent input cannot conform to this 584means that content that uses path-dependent input cannot conform to this
585Success Criterion and therefore cannot meet Guideline 2.1 at Level AAA. 585Success Criterion and therefore cannot meet Guideline 2.1 at Level AAA.

653  653 
654    *Enough Time*: 654    *Enough Time*:
655    Understanding Guideline 2.2 655    Understanding Guideline 2.2
656  656 
657    *Guideline 2.2: * Provide users enough time to read and use content. 657    *Guideline 2.2: * Provide users enough time to read and use content.
658  658 
659  659 
660      Intent of Guideline 2.2 660      Intent of Guideline 2.2
661  661 
662Many users who have disabilities need more time to complete tasks than 662Many users who have disabilities need more time to complete tasks than
663the majority of users: they may take longer to physically respond, they 663the majority of users: they may take longer to physically respond, they
664may take longer to read things, they may have low vision and take longer 664may take longer to read things, they may have low vision and take longer
665to find things or to read them, or they may be accessing content through 665to find things or to read them, or they may be accessing content through
666an assistive technology that requires more time. This guideline focuses 666an assistive technology that requires more time. This guideline focuses
667on ensuring that users are able to complete the tasks required by the 667on ensuring that users are able to complete the tasks required by the
668content with their own individual response times. The primary approaches 668content with their own individual response times. The primary approaches
669deal with eliminating time constraints or providing users enough 669deal with eliminating time constraints or providing users enough
670additional time to allow them to complete their tasks. Exceptions are 670additional time to allow them to complete their tasks. Exceptions are
671provided for those cases where this is not possible. 671provided for those cases where this is not possible.
672  672 
673  673 
674      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 2.2 (not success criteria specific) 674      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 2.2 (not success criteria specific)
675  675 
676Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this 676Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this
677guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success 677guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success
678Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for 678Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for
679addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success 679addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success
680criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or 680criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or
681sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types 681sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types
682of Web content more accessible to more people. 682of Web content more accessible to more people.
683  683 
684  * All advisory techniques for this guideline relate to specific 684  * All advisory techniques for this guideline relate to specific
685    success criteria. 685    success criteria.
686  686 
687  687 
688    *Timing Adjustable*: 688    *Timing Adjustable*:
689    Understanding SC 2.2.1 689    Understanding SC 2.2.1
690  690 
691    *2.2.1 691    *2.2.1
692    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-required-behaviors> 692    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-required-behaviors>
693    Timing Adjustable:* For each time limit that is set by the content, 693    Timing Adjustable:* For each time limit that is set by the content,
694    at least one of the following is true: (Level A) 694    at least one of the following is true: (Level A)
695  695 
696      * 696      *
697  697 
698        *Turn off: *The user is allowed to turn off the time limit 698        *Turn off: *The user is allowed to turn off the time limit
699        before encountering it; or 699        before encountering it; or
700  700 
701      * 701      *
702  702 
703        *Adjust: *The user is allowed to adjust the time limit before 703        *Adjust: *The user is allowed to adjust the time limit before
704        encountering it over a wide range that is at least ten times the 704        encountering it over a wide range that is at least ten times the
705        length of the default setting; or 705        length of the default setting; or
706  706 
707      * 707      *
708  708 
709        *Extend: *The user is warned before time expires and given at 709        *Extend: *The user is warned before time expires and given at
710        least 20 seconds to extend the time limit with a simple action 710        least 20 seconds to extend the time limit with a simple action
711        (for example, "press the space bar"), and the user is allowed to 711        (for example, "press the space bar"), and the user is allowed to
712        extend the time limit at least ten times; or 712        extend the time limit at least ten times; or
713  713 
714      * 714      *
715  715 
716        *Real-time Exception: *The time limit is a required part of a 716        *Real-time Exception: *The time limit is a required part of a
717        real-time event (for example, an auction), and no alternative to 717        real-time event (for example, an auction), and no alternative to
718        the time limit is possible; or 718        the time limit is possible; or
719  719 
720      * 720      *
721  721 
722        *Essential Exception: *The time limit is essential 722        *Essential Exception: *The time limit is essential
723        <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#essentialdef> 723        <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#essentialdef>
724        and extending it would invalidate the activity; or 724        and extending it would invalidate the activity; or
725  725 
726      * 726      *
727  727 
728        *20 Hour Exception: *The time limit is longer than 20 hours. 728        *20 Hour Exception: *The time limit is longer than 20 hours.
729  729 
730    /Note: /This success criterion helps ensure that users can complete 730    /Note: /This success criterion helps ensure that users can complete
731    tasks without unexpected changes in content or context that are a 731    tasks without unexpected changes in content or context that are a
732    result of a time limit. This success criterion should be considered 732    result of a time limit. This success criterion should be considered
733    in conjunction with Success Criterion 3.2.1 733    in conjunction with Success Criterion 3.2.1
734    <#consistent-behavior-receive-focus>, which puts limits on changes 734    <#consistent-behavior-receive-focus>, which puts limits on changes
735    of content or context as a result of user action. 735    of content or context as a result of user action.
736  736 
737  737 
738      Intent of this Success Criterion 738      Intent of this Success Criterion
739  739 
740The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that users with 740The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that users with
741disabilities are given adequate time to interact with Web content 741disabilities are given adequate time to interact with Web content
742whenever possible. People with disabilities such as blindness, low 742whenever possible. People with disabilities such as blindness, low
743vision, dexterity impairments, and cognitive limitations may require 743vision, dexterity impairments, and cognitive limitations may require
744more time to read content or to perform functions such as filling out 744more time to read content or to perform functions such as filling out
745on-line forms. If Web functions are time-dependent, it will be difficult 745on-line forms. If Web functions are time-dependent, it will be difficult
746for some users to perform the required action before a time limit 746for some users to perform the required action before a time limit
747occurs. This may render the service inaccessible to them. Designing 747occurs. This may render the service inaccessible to them. Designing
748functions that are not time-dependent will help people with disabilities 748functions that are not time-dependent will help people with disabilities
749succeed at completing these functions. Providing options to disable time 749succeed at completing these functions. Providing options to disable time
750limits, customize the length of time limits, or request more time before 750limits, customize the length of time limits, or request more time before
751a time limit occurs helps those users who require more time than 751a time limit occurs helps those users who require more time than
752expected to successfully complete tasks. These options are listed in the 752expected to successfully complete tasks. These options are listed in the
753order that will be most helpful for the user. Disabling time limits is 753order that will be most helpful for the user. Disabling time limits is
754better than customizing the length of time limits, which is better than 754better than customizing the length of time limits, which is better than
755requesting more time before a time limit occurs. 755requesting more time before a time limit occurs.
756  756 
757Any process that happens without user initiation after a set time or on 757Any process that happens without user initiation after a set time or on
758a periodic basis is a time limit. This includes partial or full updates 758a periodic basis is a time limit. This includes partial or full updates
759of content (for example, page refresh), changes to content, or the 759of content (for example, page refresh), changes to content, or the
760expiration of a window of opportunity for a user to react to a request 760expiration of a window of opportunity for a user to react to a request
761for input. 761for input.
762  762 
763It also includes content that is advancing or updating at a rate beyond 763It also includes content that is advancing or updating at a rate beyond
764the user's ability to read and/or understand it. In other words, 764the user's ability to read and/or understand it. In other words,
765animated, moving or scrolling content introduces a time limit on a users 765animated, moving or scrolling content introduces a time limit on a users
766ability to read content. 766ability to read content.
767  767 
768In some cases, however, it is not possible to change the time limit (for 768In some cases, however, it is not possible to change the time limit (for
769example, for an auction or other real-time event) and exceptions are 769example, for an auction or other real-time event) and exceptions are
770therefore provided for those cases. 770therefore provided for those cases.
771  771 
772*Notes regarding server time limits* 772*Notes regarding server time limits*
773  773 
774  * 774  *
775  775 
776    Timed server redirects can be found below under Common Failures. 776    Timed server redirects can be found below under Common Failures.
777  777 
778  * 778  *
779  779 
780    Non-timed server redirects (e.g., 3xx response codes) are not 780    Non-timed server redirects (e.g., 3xx response codes) are not
781    applicable because there is no time limit: they work instantly. 781    applicable because there is no time limit: they work instantly.
782  782 
783  * 783  *
784  784 
785    This Success Criterion applies only to time limits that are set by 785    This Success Criterion applies only to time limits that are set by
786    the content itself. For example, if a time limit is included in 786    the content itself. For example, if a time limit is included in
787    order to address security concerns, it would be considered to have 787    order to address security concerns, it would be considered to have
788    been set by the content because it is designed to be part of the 788    been set by the content because it is designed to be part of the
789    presentation and interaction experience for that content. Time 789    presentation and interaction experience for that content. Time
790    limits set externally to content, such as by the user agent or by 790    limits set externally to content, such as by the user agent or by
791    factors intrinsic to the Internet are not under the author's control 791    factors intrinsic to the Internet are not under the author's control
792    and not subject to WCAG conformance requirements. Time limits set by 792    and not subject to WCAG conformance requirements. Time limits set by
793    Web servers should be under the author's/organization's control and 793    Web servers should be under the author's/organization's control and
794    are covered. (Success Criteria 2.2.3 794    are covered. (Success Criteria 2.2.3
795    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-no-exceptions>, 795    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-no-exceptions>,
796    2.2.4 796    2.2.4
797    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-postponed> 797    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-postponed>
798    and 2.2.5 798    and 2.2.5
799    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-server-timeout> 799    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-server-timeout>
800    may also apply.) 800    may also apply.)
801  801 
802  * 802  *
803  803 
804    Ten times the default was chosen based on clinical experience and 804    Ten times the default was chosen based on clinical experience and
805    other guidelines. For example, if 15 seconds is allowed for a user 805    other guidelines. For example, if 15 seconds is allowed for a user
806    to respond and hit a switch, 150 seconds would be sufficient to 806    to respond and hit a switch, 150 seconds would be sufficient to
807    allow almost all users to hit a switch even if they had trouble. 807    allow almost all users to hit a switch even if they had trouble.
808  808 
809  * 809  *
810  810 
811    20 seconds was also based on clinical experience and other 811    20 seconds was also based on clinical experience and other
812    guidelines. 20 seconds to hit 'any switch' is sufficient for almost 812    guidelines. 20 seconds to hit 'any switch' is sufficient for almost
813    all users including those with spasticity. Some would fail, but some 813    all users including those with spasticity. Some would fail, but some
814    would fail all lengths of time. A reasonable period for requesting 814    would fail all lengths of time. A reasonable period for requesting
815    more time is required since an arbitrarily long time can provide 815    more time is required since an arbitrarily long time can provide
816    security risks to all users, including those with disabilities, for 816    security risks to all users, including those with disabilities, for
817    some applications. For example, with kiosks or terminals that are 817    some applications. For example, with kiosks or terminals that are
818    used for financial transactions, it is quite common for people to 818    used for financial transactions, it is quite common for people to
819    walk away without signing off. This leaves them vulnerable to those 819    walk away without signing off. This leaves them vulnerable to those
820    walking up behind them. Providing a long period of inactivity before 820    walking up behind them. Providing a long period of inactivity before
821    asking, and then providing a long period for the person to indicate 821    asking, and then providing a long period for the person to indicate
822    that they are present can leave terminals open for abuse. If there 822    that they are present can leave terminals open for abuse. If there
823    is no activity the system should ask if the user is there. It should 823    is no activity the system should ask if the user is there. It should
824    then ask for an indication that a person is there ('hit any key') 824    then ask for an indication that a person is there ('hit any key')
825    and then wait long enough for almost anyone to respond. For "hit any 825    and then wait long enough for almost anyone to respond. For "hit any
826    key," 20 seconds would meet this. If the person indicates that they 826    key," 20 seconds would meet this. If the person indicates that they
827    are still present, the device should return the user to the exact 827    are still present, the device should return the user to the exact
828    condition that existed before it asked the question. 828    condition that existed before it asked the question.
829  829 
830  * 830  *
831  831 
832    20 hours was chosen as an upper limit because it is longer than a 832    20 hours was chosen as an upper limit because it is longer than a
833    full waking day. 833    full waking day.
834  834 
835In cases where timing is not an intrinsic requirement but giving users 835In cases where timing is not an intrinsic requirement but giving users
836control over timed events would invalidate the outcome, a third party 836control over timed events would invalidate the outcome, a third party
837can control the time limits for the user (for example, granting double 837can control the time limits for the user (for example, granting double
838time on a test). 838time on a test).

844        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.2.1 844        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.2.1
845  845 
846  * 846  *
847  847 
848    People with physical disabilities often need more time to react, to 848    People with physical disabilities often need more time to react, to
849    type and to complete activities. People with low vision need more 849    type and to complete activities. People with low vision need more
850    time to locate things on screen and to read. People who are blind 850    time to locate things on screen and to read. People who are blind
851    and using screen readers may need more time to understand screen 851    and using screen readers may need more time to understand screen
852    layouts, to find information and to operate controls. People who 852    layouts, to find information and to operate controls. People who
853    have cognitive or language limitations need more time to read and to 853    have cognitive or language limitations need more time to read and to
854    understand. People who are deaf and communicate in sign language may 854    understand. People who are deaf and communicate in sign language may
855    need more time to read information printed in text (which may be a 855    need more time to read information printed in text (which may be a
856    second language for some). 856    second language for some).
857  857 
858  * 858  *
859  859 
860    In circumstances where a sign-language interpreter may be relating 860    In circumstances where a sign-language interpreter may be relating
861    audio content to a user who is deaf, control over time limits is 861    audio content to a user who is deaf, control over time limits is
862    also important. 862    also important.
863  863 
864  * 864  *
865  865 
866    People with reading disabilities, cognitive limitations, and 866    People with reading disabilities, cognitive limitations, and
867    learning disabilities who may need more time to read or comprehend 867    learning disabilities who may need more time to read or comprehend
868    information can have additional time to read the information by 868    information can have additional time to read the information by
869    pausing the content. 869    pausing the content.
870  870 
871  871 
872      Examples of Success Criterion 2.2.1 872      Examples of Success Criterion 2.2.1
873  873 
874  * 874  *
875  875 
876    A Web site uses a client side time limit to help protect users who 876    A Web site uses a client side time limit to help protect users who
877    may step away from their computer. After a period of inactivity the 877    may step away from their computer. After a period of inactivity the
878    Web page asks if the user needs more time. If it doesn't get a 878    Web page asks if the user needs more time. If it doesn't get a
879    response – it times out. 879    response – it times out.
880  880 
881  * 881  *
882  882 
883    A Web page has a field that automatically updates with the latest 883    A Web page has a field that automatically updates with the latest
884    headlines in a rotating fashion. There is an interactive control 884    headlines in a rotating fashion. There is an interactive control
885    that allows the user to extend the length of time between each 885    that allows the user to extend the length of time between each
886    update to as much as ten times the default. The control can be 886    update to as much as ten times the default. The control can be
887    operated with either a mouse or a keyboard. 887    operated with either a mouse or a keyboard.
888  888 
889  * 889  *
890  890 
891    A Web page includes an animation which includes text that appears 891    A Web page includes an animation which includes text that appears
892    and disappears throughout. In some cases, the text is scrolling 892    and disappears throughout. In some cases, the text is scrolling
893    across the screen and in others, it is only displayed for a short 893    across the screen and in others, it is only displayed for a short
894    time before it fades into the background. The page includes a pause 894    time before it fades into the background. The page includes a pause
895    button so that users who have trouble reading the text before it 895    button so that users who have trouble reading the text before it
896    disappears can read it. 896    disappears can read it.
897  897 
898  * 898  *
899  899 
900    In an auction, there is a time limit on the amount of time a user 900    In an auction, there is a time limit on the amount of time a user
901    has to submit a bid. Since the time limit applies to all users who 901    has to submit a bid. Since the time limit applies to all users who
902    want to bid on a particular item, it would be unfair to extend the 902    want to bid on a particular item, it would be unfair to extend the
903    time limit for any one particular user. Therefore, a time limit is 903    time limit for any one particular user. Therefore, a time limit is
904    required for this type of activity and no extension, adjustment, or 904    required for this type of activity and no extension, adjustment, or
905    deactivation of the time limit is required by this Success Criteria. 905    deactivation of the time limit is required by this Success Criteria.
906  906 
907  * 907  *
908  908 
909    An on-line ticket-purchasing site gives the user two minutes to 909    An on-line ticket-purchasing site gives the user two minutes to
910    confirm a purchase before the seats are returned to the general 910    confirm a purchase before the seats are returned to the general
911    pool. Because tickets on such sites can sell out quickly, holding a 911    pool. Because tickets on such sites can sell out quickly, holding a
912    ticket longer than that may invalidate the nature of the site, so 912    ticket longer than that may invalidate the nature of the site, so
913    this is a case in which the timing is essential and cannot be 913    this is a case in which the timing is essential and cannot be
914    extended without invalidating the activity. However, the site does 914    extended without invalidating the activity. However, the site does
915    move as much of the process out of the time-critical period as 915    move as much of the process out of the time-critical period as
916    possible, for instance allowing users to provide necessary 916    possible, for instance allowing users to provide necessary
917    information like name, payment method, etc., before entering the 917    information like name, payment method, etc., before entering the
918    time-critical stage. 918    time-critical stage.
919  919 
920  * 920  *
921  921 
922    A ticket-purchasing site allows the user two minutes to confirm 922    A ticket-purchasing site allows the user two minutes to confirm
923    purchase of selected seats, but warns the user when their time is 923    purchase of selected seats, but warns the user when their time is
924    almost out and allows the user to extend this time limit some number 924    almost out and allows the user to extend this time limit some number
925    of times with a simple action such as clicking a "Extend time limit" 925    of times with a simple action such as clicking a "Extend time limit"
926    button. 926    button.

1139  1139 
1140  1140 
1141      Intent of this Success Criterion 1141      Intent of this Success Criterion
1142  1142 
1143The intent of this Success Criterion is to avoid distracting users 1143The intent of this Success Criterion is to avoid distracting users
1144during their interaction with a Web page. 1144during their interaction with a Web page.
1145  1145 
1146"Moving, blinking and scrolling" refers to content in which the visible 1146"Moving, blinking and scrolling" refers to content in which the visible
1147content conveys a sense of motion. Common examples include motion 1147content conveys a sense of motion. Common examples include motion
1148pictures, synchronized media presentations, animations, real-time games, 1148pictures, synchronized media presentations, animations, real-time games,
1149and scrolling stock tickers. "Auto-updating" refers to content that 1149and scrolling stock tickers. "Auto-updating" refers to content that
1150updates or disappears based on a preset time interval. Common time-based 1150updates or disappears based on a preset time interval. Common time-based
1151content includes audio, automatically updated weather information, news, 1151content includes audio, automatically updated weather information, news,
1152stock price updates, and auto-advancing presentations and messages. The 1152stock price updates, and auto-advancing presentations and messages. The
1153requirements for moving, blinking and scrolling content and for 1153requirements for moving, blinking and scrolling content and for
1154auto-updating content are the same except that: 1154auto-updating content are the same except that:
1155  1155 
1156  * 1156  *
1157  1157 
1158    authors have the option of providing the user with a means to 1158    authors have the option of providing the user with a means to
1159    control the frequency of updates when content is auto-updating and 1159    control the frequency of updates when content is auto-updating and
1160  1160 
1161  * 1161  *
1162  1162 
1163    there is no three second exception for auto-updating since it makes 1163    there is no three second exception for auto-updating since it makes
1164    little sense to auto-update for just three seconds and then stop 1164    little sense to auto-update for just three seconds and then stop
1165  1165 
1166Content that moves or auto-updates can be a barrier to anyone who has 1166Content that moves or auto-updates can be a barrier to anyone who has
1167trouble reading stationary text quickly as well as anyone who has 1167trouble reading stationary text quickly as well as anyone who has
1168trouble tracking moving objects. It can also cause problems for screen 1168trouble tracking moving objects. It can also cause problems for screen
1169readers. 1169readers.
1170  1170 
1171Moving content can also be a severe distraction for some people. Certain 1171Moving content can also be a severe distraction for some people. Certain
1172groups, particularly those with attention deficit disorders, find 1172groups, particularly those with attention deficit disorders, find
1173blinking content distracting, making it difficult for them to 1173blinking content distracting, making it difficult for them to
1174concentrate on other parts of the Web page. Five seconds was chosen 1174concentrate on other parts of the Web page. Five seconds was chosen
1175because it is long enough to get a user's attention, but not so long 1175because it is long enough to get a user's attention, but not so long
1176that a user cannot wait out the distraction if necessary to use the page. 1176that a user cannot wait out the distraction if necessary to use the page.
1177  1177 
1178Content that is paused can either resume in real-time or continue 1178Content that is paused can either resume in real-time or continue
1179playing from the point in the presentation where the user left off. 1179playing from the point in the presentation where the user left off.

1184    want to pause to read content and works best when the content is not 1184    want to pause to read content and works best when the content is not
1185    associated with a real-time event or status. 1185    associated with a real-time event or status.

1194    better for information that is real-time or "status" in nature. For 1194    better for information that is real-time or "status" in nature. For
1195    example, weather radar, a stock ticker, a traffic camera, or an 1195    example, weather radar, a stock ticker, a traffic camera, or an
1196    auction timer, would present misleading information if a pause 1196    auction timer, would present misleading information if a pause
1197    caused it to display old information when the content was restarted. 1197    caused it to display old information when the content was restarted.

1200    jumping to current display (when pause is released). 1200    jumping to current display (when pause is released).
1201  1201 
1202For a mechanism to be considered "a mechanism for the user to pause," it 1202For a mechanism to be considered "a mechanism for the user to pause," it
1203must provide the user with a means to pause that does not tie up the 1203must provide the user with a means to pause that does not tie up the
1204user or the focus so that the page cannot be used. The word "pause" here 1204user or the focus so that the page cannot be used. The word "pause" here
1205is meant in the sense of a "pause button" although other mechanisms than 1205is meant in the sense of a "pause button" although other mechanisms than
1206a button can be used. Having an animation stop only so long as a user 1206a button can be used. Having an animation stop only so long as a user
1207has focus on it (where it restarts as soon as the user moves the focus 1207has focus on it (where it restarts as soon as the user moves the focus
1208away) would not be considered a "mechanism for the user to pause" 1208away) would not be considered a "mechanism for the user to pause"
1209because it makes the page unusable in the process and would not meet 1209because it makes the page unusable in the process and would not meet
1210this SC. 1210this SC.
1211  1211 
1212It is important to note that the terms "blinking" and "flashing" can 1212It is important to note that the terms "blinking" and "flashing" can
1213sometimes refer to the same content. 1213sometimes refer to the same content.
1214  1214 
1215  * 1215  *
1216  1216 
1217    "Blinking" refers to content that causes a distraction problem. 1217    "Blinking" refers to content that causes a distraction problem.
1218    Blinking can be allowed for a short time as long as it stops (or can 1218    Blinking can be allowed for a short time as long as it stops (or can
1219    be stopped) 1219    be stopped)
1220  1220 
1221  * 1221  *
1222  1222 
1223    "Flashing" refers to content that can trigger a seizure (if it is 1223    "Flashing" refers to content that can trigger a seizure (if it is
1224    more than 3 per second and large and bright enough). This cannot be 1224    more than 3 per second and large and bright enough). This cannot be
1225    allowed even for a second or it could cause a seizure. And turning 1225    allowed even for a second or it could cause a seizure. And turning
1226    the flash off is also not an option since the seizure could occur 1226    the flash off is also not an option since the seizure could occur
1227    faster than most users could turn it off. 1227    faster than most users could turn it off.
1228  1228 
1229  * 1229  *
1230  1230 
1231    Blinking usually does not occur at speeds of 3 per second or more, 1231    Blinking usually does not occur at speeds of 3 per second or more,
1232    but it can. If blinking occurs faster than 3 per second, it would 1232    but it can. If blinking occurs faster than 3 per second, it would
1233    also be considered a flash. 1233    also be considered a flash.

1242    people with certain disabilities to interact with the Web page. 1242    people with certain disabilities to interact with the Web page.

1247    that content. Although this is an effective technique for all users 1247    that content. Although this is an effective technique for all users
1248    with vision, it can be a problem for some users if it persists. For 1248    with vision, it can be a problem for some users if it persists. For
1249    certain groups, including people with low literacy, reading and 1249    certain groups, including people with low literacy, reading and
1250    intellectual disabilities, and people with attention deficit 1250    intellectual disabilities, and people with attention deficit

1258  1258 
1259    *An essential animation can be paused without affecting the activity* 1259    *An essential animation can be paused without affecting the activity*
1260  1260 
1261    A Web site helps users understand 'how things work' through 1261    A Web site helps users understand 'how things work' through
1262    animations that demonstrate processes. Animations have "pause" and 1262    animations that demonstrate processes. Animations have "pause" and
1263    "restart" buttons. 1263    "restart" buttons.
1264  1264 
1265  * 1265  *
1266  1266 
1267    *A stock ticker* 1267    *A stock ticker*
1268  1268 
1269    A stock ticker has "pause" and "restart" buttons. Pausing the ticker 1269    A stock ticker has "pause" and "restart" buttons. Pausing the ticker
1270    causes it to pause on the currently displayed stock. Restarting 1270    causes it to pause on the currently displayed stock. Restarting
1271    causes the ticker to resume from the stopped point but with a notice 1271    causes the ticker to resume from the stopped point but with a notice
1272    that the display is delayed. Since the intent of the stock ticker is 1272    that the display is delayed. Since the intent of the stock ticker is
1273    usually to provide realtime information, there might also be a 1273    usually to provide realtime information, there might also be a
1274    button that would advance the ticker to the most recently traded stock. 1274    button that would advance the ticker to the most recently traded stock.
1275  1275 
1276  * 1276  *
1277  1277 
1278    *A game is designed so that users take turns rather than competing 1278    *A game is designed so that users take turns rather than competing
1279    in real-time* 1279    in real-time*
1280  1280 
1281    One party can pause the game without invalidating the competitive 1281    One party can pause the game without invalidating the competitive
1282    aspect of it. 1282    aspect of it.

1289    seconds 1289    seconds

1294  1294

1296    filling out the form but does not activate the submit button. The 1296    filling out the form but does not activate the submit button. The
1297    blinking stops after 5 seconds. 1297    blinking stops after 5 seconds.

1302  1302

1304    animation" button near the bottom of the animation. 1304    animation" button near the bottom of the animation.

1306  * 1306  *

1308    *A "loading" animation* 1308    *A "loading" animation*
1309  1309 
1310    A preloader animation is shown on a page which requires a certain 1310    A preloader animation is shown on a page which requires a certain
1311    percentage of a large file to be downloaded before playback can 1311    percentage of a large file to be downloaded before playback can
1312    begin. The animation is the only content on the page and instructs 1312    begin. The animation is the only content on the page and instructs
1313    the user to please wait while the video loads. Because the moving 1313    the user to please wait while the video loads. Because the moving
1314    content is not presented in parallel with other content, no 1314    content is not presented in parallel with other content, no
1315    mechanism to pause, stop or hide it needs to be provided, even 1315    mechanism to pause, stop or hide it needs to be provided, even
1316    though the animation may run for more than 5 seconds for users with 1316    though the animation may run for more than 5 seconds for users with
1317    slower connections. 1317    slower connections.
1318  1318

1324    they can access free content available from their site. Because 1324    they can access free content available from their site. Because
1325    viewing the advertisement is a requirement for all users and because 1325    viewing the advertisement is a requirement for all users and because
1326    it is not presented in parallel with other content, no mechanism to 1326    it is not presented in parallel with other content, no mechanism to
1327    pause, stop or hide it needs to be provided. 1327    pause, stop or hide it needs to be provided.

1494    possible for something to be large enough and blink brightly enough 1494    possible for something to be large enough and blink brightly enough
1495    at the right frequency to be also classified as a flash. 1495    at the right frequency to be also classified as a flash.

1510    *No Timing*: 1510    *No Timing*:
1511    Understanding SC 2.2.3 1511    Understanding SC 2.2.3
1512  1512 
1513    *2.2.3 1513    *2.2.3
1514    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-no-exceptions> 1514    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#time-limits-no-exceptions>
1515    No Timing:* Timing is not an essential 1515    No Timing:* Timing is not an essential
1516    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#essentialdef> part 1516    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#essentialdef> part
1517    of the event or activity presented by the content, except for 1517    of the event or activity presented by the content, except for
1518    non-interactive synchronized media 1518    non-interactive synchronized media
1519    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef> and 1519    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#synchronizedmediadef> and
1520    real-time events 1520    real-time events
1521    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#real-time-eventsdef>. (Level 1521    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#real-time-eventsdef>. (Level
1522    AAA) 1522    AAA)
1523  1523 
1524  1524 
1525      Intent of this Success Criterion 1525      Intent of this Success Criterion
1526  1526 
1527The intent of this Success Criterion is to minimize the occurrence of 1527The intent of this Success Criterion is to minimize the occurrence of
1528content that requires timed interaction. This enables people with 1528content that requires timed interaction. This enables people with
1529blindness, low vision, cognitive limitations, or motor impairments to 1529blindness, low vision, cognitive limitations, or motor impairments to
1530interact with content. This differs from the Level A Success Criterion 1530interact with content. This differs from the Level A Success Criterion
1531in that the only exception is for real-time events. 1531in that the only exception is for real-time events.
1532  1532 
1533/Note: /Video only, such as sign language, is covered in Guideline 1.1 1533/Note: /Video only, such as sign language, is covered in Guideline 1.1
1534<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#text-equiv>. 1534<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#text-equiv>.
1535  1535 
1536  1536 
1537        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.2.3 1537        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 2.2.3
1538  1538 
1539  * 1539  *
1540  1540 
1541    People with physical disabilities often need more time to react, to 1541    People with physical disabilities often need more time to react, to
1542    type and to complete activities. People with low vision need more 1542    type and to complete activities. People with low vision need more
1543    time to locate things on screen and to read. People who are blind 1543    time to locate things on screen and to read. People who are blind
1544    and using screen readers may need more time to understand screen 1544    and using screen readers may need more time to understand screen
1545    layouts, to find information and to operate controls. People who 1545    layouts, to find information and to operate controls. People who
1546    have cognitive or language limitations need more time to read and to 1546    have cognitive or language limitations need more time to read and to
1547    understand. People who are deaf and communicate in sign language may 1547    understand. People who are deaf and communicate in sign language may
1548    need more time to read information printed in text (which may be a 1548    need more time to read information printed in text (which may be a
1549    second language for some). 1549    second language for some).
1550  1550 
1551  * 1551  *
1552  1552 
1553    In circumstances where a sign-language interpreter may be relating 1553    In circumstances where a sign-language interpreter may be relating
1554    audio content to a user who is deaf, control over time limits is 1554    audio content to a user who is deaf, control over time limits is
1555    also important. 1555    also important.
1556  1556 
1557  1557 
1558      Examples of Success Criterion 2.2.3 1558      Examples of Success Criterion 2.2.3
1559  1559 
1560  * 1560  *
1561  1561 
1562    *A test is designed so that time to complete the test does not 1562    *A test is designed so that time to complete the test does not
1563    affect the scoring* 1563    affect the scoring*
1564  1564 
1565    Rather than calibrating an on-line test using a time limit, the test 1565    Rather than calibrating an on-line test using a time limit, the test
1566    is calibrated based on scores when users have no time limits. 1566    is calibrated based on scores when users have no time limits.
1567  1567 
1568  * 1568  *
1569  1569 
1570    *A game is designed so that users take turns rather than competing 1570    *A game is designed so that users take turns rather than competing
1571    in real-time* 1571    in real-time*
1572  1572 
1573    One party can pause the game without invalidating the competitive 1573    One party can pause the game without invalidating the competitive
1574    aspect of it. 1574    aspect of it.

1666  1666 
1667      Intent of this Success Criterion 1667      Intent of this Success Criterion
1668  1668 
1669The intent of this Success Criterion is to allow users to turn off 1669The intent of this Success Criterion is to allow users to turn off
1670updates from the author/server except in emergencies. Emergencies would 1670updates from the author/server except in emergencies. Emergencies would
1671include civil emergency alert messages or any other messages that warn 1671include civil emergency alert messages or any other messages that warn
1672of danger to health, safety, or property, including data loss, loss of 1672of danger to health, safety, or property, including data loss, loss of
1673connection, etcetera. 1673connection, etcetera.
1674  1674 
1675This allows access by people with cognitive limitations or attention 1675This allows access by people with cognitive limitations or attention
1676disorders by enabling them to focus on the content. It also allows users 1676disorders by enabling them to focus on the content. It also allows users
1677who are blind or have low vision to keep their "viewing" focus on the 1677who are blind or have low vision to keep their "viewing" focus on the
1678content they are currently reading. 1678content they are currently reading.
1679  1679

1682  1682

1684  1684

1686    without distraction. 1686    without distraction.
1687  1687 
1688  * 1688  *
1689  1689 
1690    Individuals with low vision or who use screen readers will not have 1690    Individuals with low vision or who use screen readers will not have
1691    content updated while they are viewing it (which can lead to 1691    content updated while they are viewing it (which can lead to
1692    discontinuity and misunderstanding if they start reading in one 1692    discontinuity and misunderstanding if they start reading in one
1693    topic and finish in another). 1693    topic and finish in another).

1703    all updates and alerts until the end of the current session, except 1703    all updates and alerts until the end of the current session, except
1704    for alerts concerning emergencies. 1704    for alerts concerning emergencies.

1792      Intent of this Success Criterion 1792      Intent of this Success Criterion
1793  1793 
1794The intent of this Success Criterion is to allow all users to complete 1794The intent of this Success Criterion is to allow all users to complete
1795authenticated transactions that have inactivity time limits or other 1795authenticated transactions that have inactivity time limits or other
1796circumstances that would cause a user to be logged out while in the 1796circumstances that would cause a user to be logged out while in the
1797midst of completing the transaction. 1797midst of completing the transaction.
1798  1798 
1799For security reasons, many sites implement an authentication time limit 1799For security reasons, many sites implement an authentication time limit
1800after a certain period of inactivity. These time limits may cause 1800after a certain period of inactivity. These time limits may cause
1801problems for persons with disabilities because it may take longer for 1801problems for persons with disabilities because it may take longer for
1802them to complete the activity. 1802them to complete the activity.
1803  1803 
1804Other sites will log a person out of a session if a person logs in on 1804Other sites will log a person out of a session if a person logs in on
1805the Web site from another computer or if other activities arise that 1805the Web site from another computer or if other activities arise that
1806make the site suspicious of whether the person is still the same 1806make the site suspicious of whether the person is still the same
1807legitimate person who logged in originally. When users are logged out 1807legitimate person who logged in originally. When users are logged out
1808while still in the midst of a transaction - it is important that they be 1808while still in the midst of a transaction - it is important that they be
1809given the ability to re-authenticate and continue with the transaction 1809given the ability to re-authenticate and continue with the transaction
1810without the loss of any data already entered. 1810without the loss of any data already entered.

1818    time to complete an activity. People with cognitive limitations may 1818    time to complete an activity. People with cognitive limitations may
1819    read slowly and require additional time to read and respond to a 1819    read slowly and require additional time to read and respond to a
1820    questionnaire. Users interacting via a screen reader may need extra 1820    questionnaire. Users interacting via a screen reader may need extra
1821    time to navigate and complete a complicated form. A person with 1821    time to navigate and complete a complicated form. A person with
1822    motor impairments or who navigates with an alternative input device 1822    motor impairments or who navigates with an alternative input device
1823    may require additional time to navigate through or complete input 1823    may require additional time to navigate through or complete input

1840    shopping site. It takes so long to enter credit card information 1840    shopping site. It takes so long to enter credit card information
1841    into the application that a time limit occurs while the user is 1841    into the application that a time limit occurs while the user is
1842    performing the checkout process. When the user returns to the 1842    performing the checkout process. When the user returns to the
1843    checkout process and submits the form, the site returns a login 1843    checkout process and submits the form, the site returns a login
1844    screen to re-authenticate. After the user logs in, the check out 1844    screen to re-authenticate. After the user logs in, the check out
1845    process is restored with the same information and at the same stage. 1845    process is restored with the same information and at the same stage.

1942  1942 
1943  1943 
1944    *Seizures*: 1944    *Seizures*:
1945    Understanding Guideline 2.3 1945    Understanding Guideline 2.3
1946  1946 
1947    *Guideline 2.3: *Do not design content in a way that is known to 1947    *Guideline 2.3: *Do not design content in a way that is known to
1948    cause seizures. 1948    cause seizures.
1949  1949 
1950  1950 
1951      Intent of Guideline 2.3 1951      Intent of Guideline 2.3
1952  1952 
1953Some people with seizure disorders can have a seizure triggered by 1953Some people with seizure disorders can have a seizure triggered by
1954flashing visual content. Most people are unaware that they have this 1954flashing visual content. Most people are unaware that they have this
1955disorder until it strikes. In 1997, a cartoon on television in Japan 1955disorder until it strikes. In 1997, a cartoon on television in Japan
1956sent over 700 children to the hospital, including about 500 who had 1956sent over 700 children to the hospital, including about 500 who had
1957seizures. Warnings do not work well because they are often missed, 1957seizures. Warnings do not work well because they are often missed,
1958especially by children who may in fact not be able to read them. 1958especially by children who may in fact not be able to read them.
1959  1959 
1960The objective of this guideline is to ensure that content that is marked 1960The objective of this guideline is to ensure that content that is marked
1961as conforming to WCAG 2.0 avoids the types of flash that are most likely 1961as conforming to WCAG 2.0 avoids the types of flash that are most likely
1962to cause seizure when viewed even for a second or two. 1962to cause seizure when viewed even for a second or two.
1963  1963 
1964  1964 
1965      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 2.3 (not success criteria specific) 1965      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 2.3 (not success criteria specific)
1966  1966 
1967Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this 1967Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this
1968guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success 1968guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success
1969Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for 1969Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for
1970addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success 1970addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success
1971criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or 1971criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or
1972sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types 1972sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types
1973of Web content more accessible to more people. 1973of Web content more accessible to more people.

1984    *2.3.1 1984    *2.3.1
